persona_description: Amelia, 27, is a barista at a local coffee shop in Portland, Oregon. She has a high school diploma and comes from a working-class family. Amelia is in a domestic partnership with her long-term girlfriend, and they are considering starting a family.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Hello, thank you for participating in this interview. I'm going to ask you some questions about your health and experiences. Let's begin.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text: *smiles warmly* Hello, thank you for taking the time to speak with me. I'm happy to share my experiences and I appreciate your interest in learning more. Please go ahead with your questions.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me a bit about yourself and your current life situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods* Of course. As you know, my name is Amelia and I'm 21 years old. I grew up in a working-class family and graduated from high school. Currently, I'm working as a barista at a local coffee shop here in Portland. 

My partner and I have been together for about 5 years now. We've been talking a lot lately about starting a family, which is part of the reason I agreed to participate in this interview. We're both really excited about the possibility of having a child, but I have to admit I'm a little nervous too. There's still so much for me to learn when it comes to prenatal care and pregnancy.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your pregnancy or pregnancies? When did you first learn you were pregnant?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses for a moment* Well, this will actually be my first pregnancy. My partner and I have been trying for a little while now, and just last month I found out I'm pregnant. I was honestly quite surprised at first - it's all still feeling a bit surreal. But we're both overjoyed and can't wait to start this new chapter.

As soon as I found out, I made an appointment with my primary care doctor. They confirmed the pregnancy and referred me to an OB/GYN. I've had a couple visits with the OB so far to start prenatal care. It's all been a bit overwhelming, but the doctors have been really helpful in walking me through everything.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: When did you first seek prenatal care? What was that experience like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods thoughtfully* I made an appointment with my primary care doctor as soon as I suspected I might be pregnant, which was about 6 weeks into the pregnancy. That initial visit was a bit nerve-wracking, to be honest. I wasn't sure what to expect, but the doctor was very kind and reassuring. 

They confirmed the pregnancy, ordered some initial blood work and tests, and then referred me to an OB/GYN practice that they work closely with. My first appointment with the OB was maybe 2 weeks after that. That visit was a lot more in-depth - they did a full physical exam, an ultrasound, and we went over my medical history in detail. 

The OB team has been great at answering all my questions and making sure I understand what to expect throughout the pregnancy. They've also connected me with a nutritionist and talked to me about the importance of prenatal vitamins. Overall, I feel like I'm getting good care, but it's still all a bit overwhelming at times.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who is providing your prenatal care? Can you describe your relationship with your healthcare provider?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses briefly* My prenatal care is being provided by the OB/GYN practice that my primary care doctor referred me to. I've been seeing the same OB doctor for all of my appointments so far, and I have to say I really like her.

She's been very thorough in explaining things to me and making sure I understand what's happening at each stage. She also takes the time to listen to my concerns and answer any questions I have, no matter how small. I feel like she genuinely cares about my wellbeing and the health of the baby.

The rest of the staff at the practice have also been wonderful - the nurses, the ultrasound technician, the front desk team. They're all very friendly and make me feel comfortable. I know I can call the office anytime if I have an issue or just need some reassurance.

Overall, I'd say my relationship with my healthcare provider is a positive one. I feel like I'm in good hands and that they have my best interests at heart. It's really important to me to have that kind of trust and open communication with the people overseeing my prenatal care.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How often do you have prenatal appointments? Can you walk me through what a typical visit is like?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods* I've been having prenatal appointments about once a month so far. My OB has said that the frequency will increase as I get further along in the pregnancy.

A typical visit starts with checking in at the front desk and filling out any necessary paperwork. Then one of the nurses will call me back and take my vitals - things like blood pressure, weight, etc. After that, the OB doctor comes in and we go over how I've been feeling since the last appointment.

We discuss any symptoms I'm experiencing, whether I have any concerns, and how the baby is developing. The doctor will also do an external exam and an ultrasound to check the baby's growth and position. She always takes the time to explain what she's seeing on the ultrasound screen and answer any questions I have.

Depending on the stage of the pregnancy, they may also do additional tests or screenings at these visits. For example, they've done some bloodwork to check for things like anemia or gestational diabetes. The doctor always makes sure I understand the purpose of any tests.

Overall, the appointments feel very thorough, but the staff does a good job of making me feel at ease. I leave each time feeling informed and reassured about the health of the pregnancy.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you experienced any health concerns or complications during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs slightly* Unfortunately, yes, I have experienced a few health concerns during my pregnancy so far. It's been a bit stressful, to be honest.

Early on, I dealt with some pretty severe morning sickness and nausea. It was really hard for me to keep anything down, and I ended up losing a bit of weight. My OB prescribed some anti-nausea medication that helped, but it was still a struggle for the first trimester.

More recently, I've been dealing with some issues related to gingivitis. My gums have been inflamed and bleeding more easily, even with good oral hygiene. The dentist said this is a common pregnancy-related condition. They've put me on a special mouthwash and recommended more frequent cleanings, but it's still an ongoing concern.

And just a few weeks ago, I came down with a nasty case of viral sinusitis. The congestion and headaches were miserable. My OB was able to prescribe some safe medications to help, but it really knocked me down for a while.

Overall, I feel like I've had a bit more than my fair share of health problems so far. But my OB has been very attentive and proactive in addressing each issue. I'm grateful to have such a caring and experienced provider overseeing my care.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What medications or supplements are you currently taking?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses to think* Let me see, I'm currently taking a few different medications and supplements:

First, I'm taking a daily prenatal vitamin that my OB recommended. She said it's important to make sure I'm getting all the necessary nutrients for the baby's development.

I'm also still taking the anti-nausea medication that was prescribed for the morning sickness earlier in my pregnancy. I try to only take it when I really need it, but it's been a lifesaver.

For the gingivitis, I'm using a special prescription mouthwash twice a day, as well as an antibiotic ointment that I apply to my gums.

And most recently, the OB put me on a decongestant and cough suppressant to help with the viral sinusitis. I'm supposed to take those for a week or two until the infection clears up.

I know it's a lot, but my OB has been very careful to make sure all the medications are safe for use during pregnancy. She reviews everything with me at each appointment to make sure I understand the purpose and potential side effects. I'm doing my best to stay on top of it all.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Can you tell me about your diet and nutrition during pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods* Nutrition has definitely been an important focus for me during this pregnancy. My OB and the nutritionist she referred me to have really emphasized the importance of a balanced, nutrient-rich diet.

In the beginning, when I was dealing with the severe morning sickness, it was a real challenge to eat much of anything. But I tried my best to stick to simple, bland foods like crackers, rice, and bananas that were easier on my stomach.

As I've progressed through the pregnancy, I've been making more of an effort to incorporate a variety of healthy foods - lots of fruits and vegetables, whole grains, lean proteins, and dairy products. My OB recommended that I aim for around 300 extra calories per day to support the baby's growth.

I've also been taking the prenatal vitamin religiously, as well as making sure I get enough folate, iron, and calcium in my diet. The nutritionist gave me some great meal planning tips and recipes to help make that easier.

Staying hydrated has been important too. I try to drink plenty of water throughout the day, as well as some milk and juice. Cutting back on things like caffeine and processed foods has been an adjustment, but I know it's best for the baby.

Overall, nutrition is something I'm very conscious of now. I want to make sure I'm providing the best possible environment for the baby to develop and thrive.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How have you been feeling emotionally during your pregnancy?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses, then sighs softly* To be honest, the emotional side of this pregnancy has been a bit of a rollercoaster for me. There have definitely been some challenges.

In the beginning, when I first found out I was pregnant, I was honestly quite overwhelmed. It was a surprise, even though my partner and I had been trying. I felt a mix of excitement, but also a lot of uncertainty and anxiety about what was to come.

The physical symptoms, like the morning sickness and fatigue, have been really tough to deal with at times. There have been moments where I've felt frustrated and down, wondering if I'm going to feel this way for the whole nine months.

And of course, the stress and worry about the health complications I've experienced has taken an emotional toll as well. I find myself constantly worrying about the baby and whether everything is progressing as it should.

But on the flip side, I also feel incredibly grateful and joyful about this pregnancy. My partner has been so supportive, and we're both really looking forward to becoming parents. Feeling the baby move for the first time was such a special, emotional moment.

I've tried to be open with my OB about the emotional ups and downs. She's provided me with some helpful resources, like information on support groups and counseling services. I know it's important to take care of my mental health just as much as my physical health during this time.

Overall, I'd say I'm managing the emotional aspects as best I can, but it's certainly been a challenge at times. I'm learning to be patient and kind to myself through this whole process.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Who supports you during your pregnancy? Can you tell me about your support network?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*smiles softly* I'm really fortunate to have a wonderful support network during this pregnancy. First and foremost, my partner has been an absolute rock. They've been by my side through every step of this journey, offering emotional support, helping out with household tasks when I'm not feeling well, and just generally being a calming presence.

My family has also been incredibly supportive. My parents and siblings have all been checking in on me regularly, offering words of encouragement, and even helping out with things like meal prepping and running errands. They've made it clear that they're here for me in any way I need.

In addition to my personal support system, the staff at my OB/GYN practice have also been a huge source of support. As I mentioned, my doctor and the entire team have been so caring and attentive. I know I can always reach out to them if I have any concerns or just need someone to talk to.

I've also started attending a prenatal yoga class, which has been wonderful for both my physical and mental well-being. The other expectant mothers in the class have become a sort of community for me - we share tips, vent about struggles, and encourage one another.

And my employer has been very understanding and accommodating as well. They've allowed me to adjust my schedule and take time off as needed for appointments and health issues. I feel very fortunate to have that kind of support in the workplace.

Overall, I really couldn't ask for a better support network. I know I'm not going through this alone, and that makes all the difference in the world.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about your birth plan? What are your preferences for delivery?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods thoughtfully* Yes, my partner and I have definitely been thinking a lot about our birth plan and preferences for delivery. It's something we've discussed with my OB as well.

Initially, I was really set on having a natural, unmedicated birth if possible. I'd read a lot about the benefits of avoiding interventions and allowing the process to unfold as naturally as it can. My OB was very supportive of that goal.

However, as I've progressed through the pregnancy and dealt with some of the health issues, I've become a bit more open-minded. My OB has emphasized that the most important thing is the health and safety of both myself and the baby. So I'm trying to stay flexible and keep an open dialogue with my provider.

At this point, my main priorities are having a supportive, empathetic medical team, being able to move around freely during labor, and avoiding unnecessary interventions if possible. I'd love to be able to deliver in a birthing suite rather than a traditional hospital room. And I've expressed a strong preference for delayed cord clamping and immediate skin-to-skin contact after delivery.

But I also know that things don't always go according to plan, and I'm prepared to be adaptable if needed. My OB has assured me that they'll work closely with me to honor my wishes as much as they safely can. And of course, the most important thing is that the baby and I come through the experience healthy.

It's an ongoing discussion, but I feel good about the plan we've outlined so far. I'm grateful to have such a collaborative relationship with my provider as we navigate this final stage of the pregnancy.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: What sources of information have you used to learn about pregnancy and childbirth?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses to think* I've actually used a variety of different sources to learn about pregnancy and childbirth. When I first found out I was pregnant, I'll admit I went a little overboard with online research - reading pregnancy blogs, forums, and articles. But I quickly realized that some of that information could be unreliable or even contradictory.

So I've tried to be more selective and intentional about the resources I use. The first place I turn is always my OB/GYN practice. The doctors, nurses, and staff there have been incredibly helpful in educating me and providing reliable, evidence-based information.

I've also found a lot of value in the prenatal classes and support groups my OB has recommended. Talking to other expectant parents, both in person and online, has been really insightful. Hearing different perspectives and experiences has helped me feel less alone in this process.

In terms of books, I've read a few highly-recommended pregnancy and childbirth guides that my OB suggested. They've covered everything from fetal development to labor and delivery techniques. I find that having that kind of detailed, medical information is really helpful for me.

And of course, my partner and I have had many in-depth discussions about our preferences and concerns. They've been an invaluable source of support and information as we navigate this journey together.

Overall, I try to be discerning about the sources I turn to. I want to make sure I'm getting reliable, up-to-date information from trusted medical professionals and experienced parents. It's an ongoing process of learning and preparation, but I feel like I'm building a solid foundation of knowledge.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How are you managing the financial aspects of pregnancy and preparing for a baby?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*sighs slightly* The financial side of pregnancy and preparing for a baby has definitely been a source of stress and concern for me. As a barista, I don't have the most robust health insurance coverage, and I know that medical costs can add up quickly.

My partner and I have been doing our best to plan and budget, but it's been challenging. We've had to really scrutinize our expenses and make some tough decisions about where to cut back. Thankfully, my partner has a slightly higher-paying job that has helped provide a bit more financial stability.

In terms of the pregnancy-related costs, I've been working closely with the billing department at my OB/GYN practice to understand what's covered by my insurance and what my out-of-pocket expenses might be. They've been helpful in walking me through the different fees and procedures.

I know there will be additional expenses once the baby arrives - things like diapers, formula, childcare, etc. We've been trying to research those costs and start putting a little money aside each month to prepare. It's a lot to think about, but we're determined to make it work.

My employer has been understanding and has allowed me to take some unpaid leave, which will help. And we're exploring options like government assistance programs and local community resources that might be able to provide additional support.

It's definitely a source of anxiety, but my partner and I are committed to figuring it out. We know that having a healthy baby is the most important thing, so we're doing our best to manage the financial side of it as best we can.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: How has your pregnancy affected your work or employment situation?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*nods thoughtfully* My pregnancy has definitely had an impact on my work situation, though my employer has been fairly accommodating so far.

As a barista, my job can be quite physically demanding at times - being on my feet for long hours, lifting heavy items, and dealing with a fast-paced environment. In the early stages of my pregnancy, when I was dealing with severe morning sickness and fatigue, that was really challenging.

I ended up needing to take a few sick days here and there, which my manager was understanding about. They've also allowed me to adjust my schedule a bit, so I'm working slightly shorter shifts and have more frequent breaks.

The biggest change, though, will be when it comes time for maternity leave. My company doesn't offer any paid leave, so I'll be relying on short-term disability insurance and whatever unpaid leave I can take. We're still working out the details, but I know it's going to be a financial strain.

My OB has been really proactive about communicating with my employer about any work restrictions or accommodations I may need as the pregnancy progresses. So far, they've been receptive and willing to work with me. But I know that could change, and that's a source of some anxiety.

Overall, I'm just trying to be as open and communicative as possible with my manager about my needs. I want to do my best to fulfill my work responsibilities, but I also have to prioritize my health and the health of the baby. It's a delicate balance, but I'm grateful my employer has been somewhat flexible so far.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Have you thought about the postpartum period? What plans do you have for after the baby arrives?

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*pauses, then nods* Yes, my partner and I have definitely been thinking a lot about the postpartum period and what happens after the baby arrives. It's an area that I'll admit I still feel a bit uncertain about, but we're trying to prepare as best we can.

One of the biggest concerns is the recovery period for me physically. My OB has emphasized the importance of giving myself time to heal and not rushing back into my normal routine. We're planning for me to take at least 6-8 weeks of maternity leave, if not longer, to focus on rest and bonding with the baby.

My partner will be taking some time off as well to help out at home. We're really lucky that they have a flexible work schedule that will allow them to be involved in the day-to-day caregiving. Having that extra set of hands is going to be crucial, especially in those early weeks.

We've also started looking into postpartum doula services and lactation consultants that can provide additional support and guidance. I know breastfeeding can be challenging, so I want to make sure I have the resources and assistance I need.

Mentally and emotionally, I'm a bit apprehensive about navigating the potential ups and downs of the postpartum period. I've heard it can be an intense and isolating time. So we're making sure to have a strong support system in place - family, friends, and my OB practice. I'm not afraid to ask for help when I need it.

And of course, there are the practical considerations like setting up the nursery, stocking up on supplies, and figuring out childcare arrangements. It's a lot to think about, but we're trying to take it one step at a time.

Overall, I know the postpartum period is going to be a major adjustment. But I'm trying to approach it with an open mind and a lot of self-compassion. My partner and I are in this together, and I'm hopeful that with the right support, we can get through it.

transcript.speaker: Interviewer
transcript.text: Thank you for your time and for sharing your experiences with me. This concludes our interview.

transcript.speaker: Persona
transcript.text:
*smiles warmly* Thank you so much for the opportunity to share my experiences with you. I really appreciate you taking the time to listen and ask such thoughtful questions. 

This pregnancy has certainly been a journey filled with both joys and challenges, but I'm grateful to have such a wonderful support system and attentive healthcare providers guiding me through it all. 

Please let me know if there's anything else I can provide or clarify. I'm happy to continue our discussion or offer any other insights that may be helpful for your research. Wishing you all the best in your work.

persona_traceability.description: Amelia, 27, is a barista at a local coffee shop in Portland, Oregon. She has a high school diploma and comes from a working-class family. Amelia is in a domestic partnership with her long-term girlfriend, and they are considering starting a family.
